Situation1: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The weekly study circle meets tonight to discuss a chapter they have not yet reviewed.
Story: The phone in my cubicle glows with another incoming call. I straighten my headset, ready to greet the next customer. Most days, the script is my shield—every objection, every question, I have a line ready. Today is no different; the callers are polite, their questions predictable, and I handle each with practiced calm. Yet, as the clock ticks closer to six, my mind drifts to the Buddhist study circle meeting tonight. We’re discussing a new chapter, one I haven’t had time to read. The expectation is clear: arrive prepared, contribute thoughtfully, deepen my understanding. But the calls keep coming, and my supervisor expects me to stay until the last minute, to never let a customer feel rushed. I feel the tension coil in my chest—my duty to my job, my commitment to my spiritual path. The phone rings again. I hesitate, torn between answering with my usual cheerful script and the urge to step away, to honor the quiet promise I made to myself and my sangha.
